Computers dislike this move, even though it gives White a pair of bishops.

Before going on with the king-side attack, White decide to stop the possible breakthrough on the queen-side. Unfortunately, this weakens control over b4 square, which Black knights find very attractive.

White's plan is to exchange dark-squared bishops and launch an attack on the Black king.

Black seizes the opportunity provided by White's 14.a4?! move.
Sooner or later White plans to play Bh6, which may require Qxh6. Thus, while the queen is away, the rook will protect the d3 pawn.
The knight returns to a square it was on just a move ago. Perhaps Black decided to use it in defense rather than attack, after all.

A real mistake, allowing White to finally use its trump cards.

After 24.fxg6 Nxg4 25.hxg4 fxg6 I was not sure how to proceed with the attack, so I decided to keep the bishop. 

Black should have taken the chance to equalize with 24...Nxf5 here.

Rather pointless move. The queen is hardly of any use on this square.
Rooks are preparing for an assault against Black king. Something must be done.
Rooks are preparing for an assault against Black king. Something must be done.
Rooks are preparing for an assault against Black king. Something must be done.
White's following move gives the opponent an opportunity to fall into a tactical trap.

And the trap works! It looks natural to take with a rook -- after all, how good can 27...Nxe8 28.Rxf8 Kxf8 29.Qh6+ be for Black? But a knight on a rim is better than a knight off the board, as the White's following move proves.

...and Black should accept the loss of a knight. Taking the rook only makes it worse.
